title: 103_hr4243
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" and imposes limitations on the height of buildings in the District of Columbia. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width and limits the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. The Act in the District of Columbia regulates building heights based on street width and limits the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. Structures above a certain limit must be fireproof and set back from the building's exterior walls at a distance equal to the structure's height. The Mayor may waive this requirement if it is unduly restrictive or impractical, without adversely affecting the purpose of the Act or neighboring buildings' exposure to light and air. The Act in the District of Columbia regulates building heights based on street width and limits the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. Penalties for violations have been increased to a maximum of $10,000 per day for general violations and $100,000 for violations of injunction. SEC. 3. National Capital Planning Commission's authority to enforce building height limitations is increased. The National Capital Planning Commission's authority is expanded to include approval for roof structures exceeding general limitations in the District of Columbia. This involves amending relevant Acts to involve the Commission in the approval process. The Act expands the National Capital Planning Commission's authority to approve building heights in the District of Columbia. It allows the Commission or its members to request approval for building heights and enforce height limitations. The Act amends the authority of the National Capital Planning Commission and its members to enforce height limitations on buildings and structures in the District of Columbia. Members can enforce limitations at their own expense unless authorized by the Commission. The Act amends Section 8 of the Act to regulate building heights in the District of Columbia, allowing the National Capital Planning Commission and its members to enforce limitations. The Act of June 20, 1938 is amended to clarify that the National Capital Planning Commission has the authority to enforce building height limitations in the District of Columbia as per the Act of June 6, 1924. The amendments made by this Act will apply to buildings and structures in the District of Columbia for which building permits are issued on or after March 23, 1994.
